supporting.text: Fish are cold-blooded, while mammals are warm-blooded, a fundamental biological distinction.

attacks.text: Fish are cold-blooded, while mammals are warm-blooded, a fundamental biological distinction.
Some fish exhibit regional endothermy, maintaining elevated body temperatures in certain tissues, blurring the line between cold-blooded and warm-blooded.
Regional endothermy in fish is rare and does not equate to full endothermy as seen in mammals, preserving the fundamental distinction.

supporting.text: Fish respire through gills, whereas mammals use lungs for breathing.

attacks.text: Fish respire through gills, whereas mammals use lungs for breathing.
Some fish, like lungfish, can breathe air using lungs in addition to gills.
Lungfish are a rare exception, and the vast majority of fish species rely solely on gills for respiration.
Mammals are defined by more than just respiration, such as mammary glands and hair, which fish lack.

supporting.text: Mammals give birth to live young and nurse them with milk, while fish lay eggs and do not produce milk.

attacks.text: Mammals give birth to live young and nurse them with milk, while fish lay eggs and do not produce milk.
Some fish species, like guppies and mollies, give birth to live young instead of laying eggs.
Even live-bearing fish do not nurse their young with milk, which is a defining characteristic of mammals.
The platypus is a mammal that lays eggs, showing that not all mammals give birth to live young.
The platypus still nurses its young with milk, maintaining the mammalian characteristic absent in fish.

supporting.text: Fish lack hair or fur, which is a defining characteristic of mammals.

attacks.text: Fish lack hair or fur, which is a defining characteristic of mammals.
Some fish have hair-like structures, such as the hairy frogfish, which blurs the distinction.
Hair-like structures in fish are not true hair or fur, as they lack the same biological composition and function.
Mammals are also defined by mammary glands, which fish lack, making the hair/fur argument unnecessary.

supporting.text: Fish are classified under the superclass Osteichthyes or Chondrichthyes, while mammals belong to the class Mammalia.

attacks.text: Fish are classified under the superclass Osteichthyes or Chondrichthyes, while mammals belong to the class Mammalia.
Some fish, like dolphins and whales, exhibit mammalian characteristics such as giving live birth and nursing their young.
Dolphins and whales are not fish; they are marine mammals that evolved from land-dwelling ancestors.
Early classification systems sometimes grouped fish and mammals together based on superficial similarities.
Modern taxonomy relies on genetic and anatomical evidence, clearly distinguishing fish from mammals.

supporting.text: The evolutionary lineages of fish and mammals diverged hundreds of millions of years ago, placing them in distinct biological groups.

attacks.text: The evolutionary lineages of fish and mammals diverged hundreds of millions of years ago, placing them in distinct biological groups.
Some fish exhibit traits like live birth and lactation, which are traditionally associated with mammals.
These traits in fish are rare exceptions and do not change their fundamental classification based on evolutionary lineage.
Early evolutionary ancestors of mammals may have resembled fish, suggesting a closer relationship than implied by divergence.
While common ancestry exists, the divergence is well-established, and modern fish and mammals are distinctly classified based on extensive morphological and genetic differences.
